Hearing.Statement: <opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. MARCO RUBIO, A U.S. SENATOR FROM</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. MARCO RUBIO"> FLORIDA; CHAIRMAN, CONGRESSIONAL-EXECUTIVE COMMISSION ON CHINA </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Rubio</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Chairman Rubio">All right, good morning. Good morning. This is a hearing of the Congressional-Executive Commission on China. The title of the hearing is ``Will the Hong Kong Model Survive?: An Assessment 20 Years After the Handover.''</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Rubio">We are going to have two panels testifying today. The first panel will feature the Right Honorable Lord Patten of Barnes, Christopher Patten, testifying via video link from London.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Lord Patten, in addition to serving in the House of Lords, was the last British governor of Hong Kong and oversaw the transfer to China 20 years ago this July.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Rubio">The second panel will include Joshua Wong from the Umbrella Movement, its leader, now the secretary-general of the new Hong Kong political party Demosisto.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Demosisto? Did I pronounce that? Great.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Martin Lee, barrister, founding chairman of the Democratic Party of Hong Kong, former member of the Drafting Committee for the Basic Law and former member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong from 1985 through 2008.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Lam Wing Kee, founder, Causeway Bay Books, one of the five forcibly disappeared Hong Kong booksellers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Rubio">And Ellen Bork, a writer whose work on democracy and human rights as a priority in American foreign policy, has appeared in the Wall Street Journal, the Washington Post, and the Financial Times, among other publications.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Rubio">I would also note that translating for Mr. Lam is Ms. Mak Yin-ting, a journalist and veteran of the Hong Kong Journalists Association, the territory's leading defender of press freedom.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Rubio">As has already been noted, today's hearing is timely, given the 20th anniversary this July of the British handover of Hong Kong. As we rewatch film footage and commentary of that historic day, we cannot help but take note of the pageantry, the raising and lowering of flags, the solemn handshakes, the national anthems.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Many observers describe the handover as signifying the sunset of a once-great colonial power and the ascent of a rising China. But there was and remains far more at stake.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Rubio">On that day in 1997, Lord Patten, who we will hear from momentarily, spoke of Hong Kong's unshakable destiny, a Hong Kong governed by and for the people of Hong Kong. And it is that destiny that animates today's gathering.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Rubio">However, in recent years, Beijing has consistently undermined the ``one country, two systems'' principle and has infringed on the democratic freedoms that the residents of Hong Kong are supposed to be guaranteed under the Sino-British Joint Declaration, which is an international treaty, and Hong Kong's Basic Law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Rubio">The rise of localist politicians and activists who call for greater political and legal self-determination for Hong Kong has drawn harsh reprisals from the Chinese and Hong Kong Governments.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Rubio">The Chinese Government's November 2016 interpretation of Hong Kong's Basic Law effectively prohibited two recently elected Hong Kong legislators from taking office and was viewed as a blow to Hong Kong's judicial independence.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Rubio">The Hong Kong Government is currently seeking the removal from office of four other pro-democratic legislators all along the same lines.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Rubio">In March of this year, nine activists were arrested for their participation in the Occupy Central protests in 2014, including two sitting pro-democratic lawmakers. Their arrests came less than 24 hours after the undemocratic ``election'' of Carrie Lam to serve as Hong Kong's next chief executive, which drew widespread condemnation and accusations of a retaliatory campaign aimed at punishing leaders of the Hong Kong democracy movement and suppressing dissent prior to her taking office.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Chairman Rubio">In late 2015, five Hong Kong-based booksellers, including one of today's witnesses, were disappeared or abducted to mainland China. One of these booksellers, Gui Minhai, a Swedish citizen abducted from Thailand, remains in custody in China where he will mark his 53rd birthday this coming Friday.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Chairman Rubio">The disappearances and abductions of the booksellers and their coerced, ``confessions'' which were broadcast on Hong Kong television, sent shockwaves through the city and are reflective of a larger, troubling trend in the area of press freedom and freedom of expression.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Today happens to be World Press Freedom Day and it bears mentioning that the recently released Reporters Without Borders index ranking, which ranks countries for their press freedom environment, had Hong Kong slipping four places in a single year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Chairman Rubio">In February, Senators Cardin and Cotton joined me in introducing the bipartisan Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, which would renew the United States' historical commitment to Hong Kong at a time when its autonomy is increasingly under assault.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Chairman Rubio">The legislation also establishes punitive measures against government officials in Hong Kong or mainland China who are responsible for suppressing basic freedoms.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Looking ahead, Congress will be closely watching how Hong Kong authorities and the mainland handle the 20th anniversary as well as whether Ms. Lam moves to reintroduce Article 23, widely despised anti-subversion and anti-sedition legislation first proposed in 2002, which triggered massive protests in which half-a-million Hong Kongers took to the streets.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Chairman Rubio">And for all these reasons is why we look forward to today's hearing, because without question there are many layers and complexities to our relationship with China as evidenced by the questions during yesterday's hearing for Governor Branstad to serve as U.S. Ambassador to China.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Despite the multitude of challenges, Hong Kong's future, indeed its destiny, must not be sidelined. China's assault on democratic institutions and human rights is of central importance to the people of Hong Kong and to its status as a free market, economic powerhouse and hub for international trade and investment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Chairman Rubio">We cannot allow Hong Kong to go the way of Beijing's failed authoritarianism and one-party rule.</paragraph>
<opening>[The prepared statement of Senator Rubio appears in the</opening>

<opening>STATEMENT OF HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH, A U.S. REPRESENTATIVE FROM</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">At this time, I would turn to Congressman Smith. And I would note that the congressman has another important bill up for markup. At some point, he will have to leave early, but we, as always, are appreciative of his incredible leadership on this commission and on this cause. appendix.] NEW JERSEY; COCHAIRMAN, CONGRESSIONAL-EXECUTIVE COMMISSION ON</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Representative Smith. Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman. And I want to thank you for convening this extremely important and timely hearing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Two-and-a-half years ago, tens of thousands of Hong Kong residents peacefully gathered in the streets, yellow umbrellas in hand, seeking electoral reform and greater democracy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Joshua Wong was at the forefront of that movement along with Nathan Law and Alex Chow and so many other young student leaders.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">The Umbrella Movement was not only composed of students, but included veterans of the democracy movement in Hong Kong, including the incomparable Martin Lee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">It is good to see Joshua and Martin here today, bringing together the generations of advocates committed to Hong Kong's freedom and autonomy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Joshua Wong and all those associated with the Umbrella Movement have become important symbols of Hong Kong's vitality and its freedoms. They are now part of Hong Kong's unique brand. And any effort to detain, censor, or intimidate them dangers that brand.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Over the past two years, Senator Rubio and I along with other members of the China Commission have introduced the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act. And we have worked in Congress to maintain the State Department's annual report on Hong Kong.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">We have issued strong statements of solidarity with and concern for the political prosecutions of Joshua and other Umbrella Movement leaders, the unprecedented interventions by the Chinese Government in Hong Kong's courts and political affairs, and the abductions of Hong Kong booksellers and other citizens.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">We have also discussed the erosion of Hong Kong's autonomy and freedoms with both U.S. and Chinese officials.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">I especially want to commend Senator Rubio for his leadership on human rights issues and on Hong Kong. We have worked together closely and I am honored to work with him on this commission. Senator Rubio is a true champion of the globe's oppressed and persecuted.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">As long as I have the privilege of serving as chair of the China Commission, the House chair, I promise to continue shining a light on Hong Kong.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Maintaining Hong Kong's autonomy is a critical U.S. interest. The United States also has a clear interest in Beijing abiding by its international agreements in Hong Kong and elsewhere.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">The democratic aspirations of the people of Hong Kong cannot be indefinitely suppressed. My colleagues and I promise to stand with Hong Kong and call attention to violations of basic human rights as they have occurred and, sadly, are still occurring.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Through Beijing's increasingly rough oversight of Hong Kong, though it may not be as brutal as that pursued on the mainland, it is no less pernicious. The ultimate goal is eroding Hong Kong's guaranteed freedoms and the rule of law and intimidating those who try to defend them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">This year will be the 20th anniversary of the handover of Hong Kong. And I think it is very important that Lord Christopher Patten will be testifying. He has provided insights to this commission before, always timely and always very, very incisive.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Unfortunately, it seems the territory's autonomy now looks increasingly fragile. Again, all the more reason why we need to hear from him.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">We are coming up on another anniversary as well, the 25th anniversary of the Hong Kong Policy Act. At this juncture, we should be examining both the health of the ``one country, two systems'' model and examining the very assumptions that underline U.S.-Hong Kong relations, what can be done differently, what new priorities should be set.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">The Hong Kong Policy Act of 1992 is based on the assumption that freedom, the rule of law, and autonomy promised to Hong Kong would be protected and respected. It was also based on the assumption that time was on the side of freedom, that trade and investment would eventually bring political liberalization and human rights to mainland China.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">As Chairman Rubio and I have been saying for some time, one can no longer base U.S. policy on the fantasy that China's future will be more democratic and more open.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Mainland China has become more repressive under Xi Jinping, not less. Prosperity has turned a poor authoritarian country into a rich authoritarian country with predictable results for China's rights defenders, ethnic and religious groups, labor and democracy advocates, foreign businesses, and Hong Kong's autonomy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Some will argue that the best course of action would be to retreat into a hard realism, recognizing China's interests and spheres of influence to protect U.S. interests.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">We could ignore what is happening in Hong Kong and shift responsibility, say, to the British or some undefined international body. I strongly disagree.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">We do not need a new realism to govern our China policy. Instead, we need a new idealism, a renewed commitment to democratic ideals, to human rights and the rule of law in ways that compete directly with the Chinese model in Asia, Africa, and elsewhere.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Chinese leaders need to know that the United States stands for freedom of expression, religion, Internet freedom, the rule of law, universal suffrage, an end to torture, and other fundamental human rights.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">Again, I want to thank you and would ask unanimous consent that my full statement be made a part of the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="HON. CHRISTOPHER SMITH">And I do regret we have a markup at 10 o'clock on the House side. The first bill that is up is my bill on combating human trafficking, so I have to be there to defend it.</paragraph>

Thank you, Congressman. Thank you for your leadership.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Rubio">And we will proceed here quickly via our videoconference with Lord Patten.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Rubio">We thank you for joining us today. We look forward to your testimony and our questions. And I am hoping that you can hear us clearly.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Rubio"> Lord Patten. <opening>STATEMENT OF THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES,</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">Well, thank you for joining us today. You are recognized, sir. CHRISTOPHER PATTEN, 28TH GOVERNOR OF HONG KONG, 1992-1997</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">(APPEARING LIVE VIA VIDEO TELECONFERENCE)</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">Lord Patten. First of all, I would like to thank you very much indeed for giving me the opportunity of speaking to you again. I spoke to you last in 2014 in November. And we spoke then principally about the extraordinarily moving demonstrations that were taking place in Hong Kong.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">Since then, as you have said, we have had two lots of elections which give a peculiarly Chinese meaning to the word ``election'' and are not quite the democratic events that you, Senator, and I are used to.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">I will not go through all that again. I explored those issues at some length in 2014 in relation to the Joint Declaration, the Basic Law, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. And all that is on the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">I can go back over it again if you would like, but it is perfectly clear that Hong Kong has not been given what it was promised by the new sovereign power.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">Perhaps I can just, by way of introduction, make four or five points.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">The first is one I made before, namely that Beijing, the Chinese Communists consistently argue that what happens in Hong Kong is nobody else's affair and that others should avoid interfering. Well, that is not true on two levels and indeed on a third.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">On the first level, Hong Kong's autonomy and way of life for 50 years, guaranteed under the Joint Declaration, which is an international treaty between Britain and China in which first Britain undertook that it would deliver some things to the people of Hong Kong and report on that to China.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">And today, the situation is reversed. China is supposed to keep its word to the people of Hong Kong and Britain has every right to interfere in that and argue about whether that has actually happened.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">Now, whether or not China keeps its word on the Joint Declaration over time is plainly a matter of considerable interest, which is the second reason why we have to be concerned, to the rest of the international community. Because if China breaks its word over the Joint Declaration and, by extension, the International Covenant and the Basic Law, if China breaks its word on those things, where do we trust it on other international agreements?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">And the third point is a straightforward one about Hong Kong's development. Hong Kong is a huge important international trading and economic hub. And an example of that is that there are 1,200 American companies, or perhaps more now, based in Hong Kong. So it is in America's interest and the international community's interest that Hong Kong should be well-governed and should have a reasonable balance between economic and political freedom.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">The other points I would like to make very briefly are these, that most of the people I respect in Hong Kong have argued that there has plainly been an erosion of autonomy and of the rule of law over the last few years, direct attacks on autonomy with the abductions that you referred to, and most recently the abduction of a billionaire who was plainly a bag carrier for some of the wealthiest members of the Chinese leadership in Beijing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">There has been pressure on the independence of the judiciary, which I suppose the most outrageous example of that was an intervention by the National People's Congress in a case which was already before the Hong Kong courts and was being properly dealt with.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">Third, there are real worries about pressure on the institutional and academic autonomy of universities. I think the view on the part of the Chinese Communist Party is that the democracy movement came out of students and came out of universities, particularly from law faculties, which has encouraged them, the Joint Liaison Office in Hong Kong and others, to interfere in university autonomy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">And freedom of speech, as you said, continues to be a problem. We have not had anything as outrageous as the appalling machete attack on a very brave journalist, Kevin Lau, in the early part of 2014. But there is still the sense of financial and physical intimidation of the press.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">The other points I just wanted to make very briefly are, first of all, we have seen, partly because any dialogue with the democracy movement and with young people and with not-so- young people in Hong Kong, any dialogue has been cut off. I think it is not unfair to say that Carrie Lam did not give the impression when she was talking to the students of being very interested in what they had to say.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">And I think as a consequence of that, we have seen what I believe to be an unwise development of what is called, politely, localism, the attempt to argue the case for Hong Kong's not just autonomy within China, but for Hong Kong's independence.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">And I think a lot of people who are totally supportive as I am of greater progress toward democracy, of standing up for the rule of law, are very, very doubtful about the wisdom of arguing for Hong Kong to have independence as a sovereign state. I simply think that that plays to the hardliners in Beijing. And I do not think it has been terribly wise.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">The last points I want to make are there. There is a lot of talk, not least on the part of political scientists, distinguished geopolitical experts like Graham Allison in the United States, about what they call the Thucydides Trap, about the almost inevitable way in which, or they say the inevitable way in which great powers are pushed into dealing aggressively with powers that are on the rise. And that obviously is a backdrop in some respects to the way we handle China in the next few years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">But the way we handle China in the next few years will largely depend on the way that China handles us and the way that China handles its responsibilities. And I think that Hong Kong, to that extent, exemplifies some of the biggest issues that we will face in the century ahead, how China takes its part in the international community, how we balance economic and political freedom, how China copes with its regional relationships.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">Now, if China cannot even handle the reasonable democratic aspirations, as it promised to do of people in Hong Kong, it does not give one a huge amount of confidence in its ability to handle wider issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">We are told that President Xi Jinping may well be going to Hong Kong at the beginning of July to swear-in Carrie Lam and to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the handover of Hong Kong to China.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="THE RIGHT HONORABLE LORD PATTEN OF BARNES">I hope that if that is true he takes the opportunity to reassure people in Hong Kong that China still stands foursquare behind what it promised back in 1984 and 1985 and later and that he, like Deng Xiaoping, believes that people in Hong Kong are perfectly capable of running their own affairs. It was a very important remark that Deng Xiaoping made back in 1984 to set the minds and hearts of people in Hong Kong at rest.</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Lord Patten appears in the</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Lord Patten appears in th"> Well, I have to say, though I think that there is much good that is still happening in Hong Kong, people's minds and hearts are not exactly at rest at the moment. appendix.] </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Rubio</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Chairman Rubio">We thank you for your testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Rubio">And I know that you are pressed on time. And we have a substantial time difference. So I will be brief unless any of the other members of the commission appear during your time on our video screen.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Rubio">And I think you have touched on this already. But how would you assess the British and Chinese Governments with regard to fulfilling their respective obligations under the Joint Declaration?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Rubio">As you looked 20 years into the future, is this what you thought it would look like? Is this what you had envisioned from both sides 20 years ago?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Or if someone had told you this is the way it was going to look like 20 years later, how would you have felt 20 years ago?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Rubio">Lord Patten. I would have been pleased that the worst that some people anticipated did not happen. There are many, Milton Friedman was one, who thought that ``one country, two systems'' was impossible. There were others who thought that, for example, even I would be leaving in a helicopter from the ballroom roof in Government House and that sooner or later there would be violence in Hong Kong. And that has not happened, though there has occasionally been some pretty rough policing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Rubio">When I was in Hong Kong, we would occasionally have a few hundred people demonstrating. It has been rather different from that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Rubio">But there has been, I think, a steady and growing erosion as Anson Chan and as Martin Lee and others have said of Hong Kong's autonomy.
